author: .bfs
content:
I'm trying to figure out if there's any value in testing for bugs that only occur before a network has finalized for the first time. 

Are there any special considerations that consensus clients take before networks finalize for the first time? Would testing a network before it finalizes for the first time be a good way to test the properties of LMD-GHOST, or are the pre-first-finalization considerations too burdensome for testing before the first epoch is finalized?

The other option I've been exploring for testing LMD-GHOST is to take a devnet that's finalized several epochs, then knock 34% of its validating stake offline to prevent finalization. That way, I can test against the remaining 65% to explore LMD-GHOST's runtime properties.

author: potuz
content: I'm not sure where this comes from but at least for prysm there's very little difference between checkpoint sync and genesis so if you find a bug that prevents syncing before the first epoch finalizes, that may affect all nodes that try checkpoint syncing until they see a new finalized checkpoint. Those are the kinds of bugs that would exponentiate if you manage to put offline many nodes at once

author: .bfs
content:
in this case the network hasn't finalized yet because of genesis rather than sync in progress. 

This is for designing attacknet faults. There's been some faults where if we run the fault before the first epoch is finalized, the impacted nodes stop attesting and need to be restarted to continue. I haven't spent much time isolating what's causing these issues because I wasn't sure if there was value in finding these kind of halts before the first epoch is finalized. 

If the pre-first-epoch code and checkpoint sync code act very similar, then it's almost definitely worth the time to isolate the issues.
